hobby.message: Any luck fixing the old typewriter?
The Council would flinch at your political literature stash.
Still chasing ghosts with analog photography?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Still scanning, far as I can tell. Hard to say what they’re finding. Been keeping busy with old typewriters. Even those are getting attention now.
Scanners haven’t stopped, just quieter since the assemblies started. I keep off the main routes. Spend afternoons restoring antique typewriters. Supplies are harder to get these days.

Yes, they're still scanning, though less predictable now. I keep myself occupied—restoring classic Olympia and Underwood typewriters. Last week someone from the district assembly borrowed my old ribbon spool. Resourceful times, I suppose.

They scan, but mostly avoid our block lately, too busy elsewhere. I restore vintage typewriters—the manual sort. Someone noticed me clacking away, asked to use it for supply lists. Odd feeling, letting old machines mix with new chaos.

Still scanning, but it’s chaos—gaps everywhere now. Decentralized orders mean even hobbies get pulled in. I restore and write on antique typewriters, habit from quieter days. My Olympia’s been busier lately—neighbors use it to print ration lists since BCI printers failed. Funny, the Council tried to erase the old ways, but now everyone wants carbon paper and ribbons. Even my journals feel less secret. Suppose, in a pinch, the obsolete has its moment again.
hobby_answer: Right, good pair. Always liked the feel of old keys.
Just a habit I kept from another life.
Harder to focus lately with the neighborhood so loud.
Some collectors say demand might rise, with all the digital trouble.
Thats all, really.
Yes, they go together. Typewriters keep things ... simple.
With the BCI stalled, I find more neighbors interested in old tools.
Last week someone wanted to borrow the Olympia. I said I needed it functional.
Strange, hearing shouts instead of printer beeps outside.
The unrest brings out more requests than usual.
They do. Antique typewriters belong in quiet spaces, away from the circuits.
I've restored three this year, mostly for my own use.
Now, with BCI printers failing, they're suddenly useful again.
Neighbors have asked to print out lists, actual ration records.
Odd watching my quiet pastime become a neighborhood service.
Feels like the machines are working overtime beneath the chaos.
It's a different kind of responsibility.
Antique typewriters and quiet bars, perfect way to step out of the stream.
Restoring the Olympia helps me think, keeps my hands busy.
Now that the city runs without central guidance, they're not just hobbies anymore.
Last week, someone logged my machine—a resource for emergency coordinators now.
Never thought I'd be handing over carbon paper and ribbon to neighbors.
Feels odd, bits of my private routine slotting into public plans.
Makes me remember how things used to run, all trust and signatures.
I write more by hand lately, too.
Always thought antique typewriters belonged to another era. Turns out, they're making a comeback here.
Restoring them was my escape from Council protocol—kept me grounded.
After signing the district autonomy order, the Olympia practically became public property.
When the BCI printers failed, neighbors lined up for typed notices and lists.
Young coordinators are fascinated by manual ribbon swaps—never saw one before.
There's satisfaction in seeing letters fixed on paper, not just screens.
Sometimes, restoring a platen or untangling typebars feels like small resistance.
I keep handwritten ledgers, too, old reflex from briefing Council staff.
Now, as order unravels, the machine connects me to what was—and what might persist.
